Scheme 1 Route to synthesize of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRD of (a) Nd/APTMS-GO, (b) APTMS-GO, and (c) GO. Fig 1 Fig. 2 FT-IR spectra of (a) Nd/APTMS-GO, (b) Nd2O3, (c) APTMS-GO, and (d) GO. Fig 2 Fig. 3 XPS analysis of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst: (a) survey spectrum, (b) Nd 3d, (c) N1s, (d) O 1s, (e) C 1s. Fig 3 Fig. 4 FE-SEM analysis of APTMS-GO (a–d), Nd/APTMS-GO (e–f) and their corresponding elemental analysis (i) and (j), respectively. Fig 4 Fig. 5 FE-SEM elemental mapping of Nd/APTMS-GO. Fig 5 Fig. 6 HR-TEM images of synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. Fig 6 Fig. 7 TGA of (a) Nd/APTMS-GO, (b) APTMS-GO, and (d) GO. Fig 7 Scheme 2 Synthesis of β-nitroamine using Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. Modi Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Conceptualization ⁎ Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Technology & Engineering, The Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda, Vadodara, Gujarat 390001, India Department of Applied Chemistry Faculty of Technology & Engineering The Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda Vadodara Gujarat 390001 India Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Technology & Engineering, The Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda, Vadodara, Gujarat 390001, India ⁎ Corresponding author. This study reveals fabrication of multifunctional catalytic system by integrating graphene oxide, neodymium trioxide (Nd2O3), and 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane (APTMS) leading to the formation of Nd/APTMS-GO. The synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst was characterized through several methods and was successfully employed as a catalyst for β-nitroamines synthesis via nitro-Mannich, i.e., aza-Henry reaction using benzaldehyde, aniline and nitromethane. This reaction was carried out without using any solvent. The reaction achieved an excellent conversion rate of 92.18 % and a high selectivity of 98.5 % towards the desired product, β-nitroamines, within time span of 8 h. Moreover, Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst revealed notable recyclability for over five cycles with moderate drop in conversion of the desired product. Introduction The incorporation of an organometallic molecule or an active C–H nucleophilic molecule into an imine is regarded as significant synthetic relevance, as this reaction generates a new functional group, i.e., amino moiety and establishes a CC bond [1–3]. This would generate derivatives of amine which are important target products for organic chemists owing to their relevance in pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals and agrochemicals [4]. The nitro-Mannich (or aza-Henry) reaction, where nitroalkanes act as nucleophiles for their addition to imines, i.e., CN, involves a nitronate anion, has garnered significant attention over the past decade amongst the imine reactions with active CH bond [2]. This reaction leads to the formation of β-nitroamines i.e. nitro-Mannich adducts which possess vicinal nitrogen bearing groups. These nitroamines serve as versatile chemical intermediates which can be readily converted to diverse array of multi-functionalized molecules, including vicinal diamines through reduction pathway or aminocarbonyl product via Nef reaction [5,6]. Numerous pharmaceuticals and natural products have been synthesized through nitro-Mannich reaction, which includes antimalarials, analgesics, antivirals, antimicrobials, antibacterials, antipsychotics, anti-HIV compounds, antidepressants and anaesthetics [7–11]. Nitromethane, the simple organic molecule possessing nitro group, frequently found in organic synthesis reaction bears a useful structure consisting of both a nucleophilic C and a modifiable nitro group [12]. It can serve as dual donor in certain nucleophilic addition to dienones, facilitating the formation of monocyclic ring [13]. β-nitroamines have been produced by organic catalyzed as well as metal catalyzed processes [14,15]. Other approaches to get these molecules include utilizing chiral imines, namely derivatives of N-tert-butylsulfinyl, which demonstrate significant utility as electrophiles due to the availability of its two enantiomers through large scale production [15]. However, the utilization of heavy metal presents some disadvantages, including a laborious work-up, catalyst separation, and waste generation. To address these concerns, researchers have focused extensively on the fabrication of heterogeneous catalysts for environmentally friendly organic synthesis [16–20]. In this context solid materials are promising compounds, with diverse support components often utilized in fabrication of catalysts [21–23]. Carbon-based materials, for instance, graphene oxide, carbon nanotubes consist of several functionalities on their surfaces that serve as active site for designing effective catalysts [24–26]. Graphene oxide (GO) has emerged as significant carbon-based support material owing to its distinctive structural as well as physical and chemical characteristics [27]. It is regarded as an excellent support material in the field of catalysis owing to its distinctive structural characteristics, such as abundant surface area and facile surface modification due to availability of tunable functionalities [28–30]. Thus, modification of the surface becomes facile due to the presence of several tunable moieties such as carbonyl functionalities, hydroxyl functional groups and epoxides which facilitates the immobilization of the surface-active moieties that drives catalysis [31]. Utilizing the potency of these debris, the characteristics of these functional groups can be altered for enabling GO to function as a multifunctional molecule through the synergistic action of decorated modified functionalities [32,33]. Thus, the heterogeneous catalysts have advantages of recyclability and reusability. Neodymium oxide (Nd2O3), the most abundant rare earth oxide serves as a lanthanide (III) member exhibit thermal stability, water insolubility and hygroscopic characteristics [34]. Moreover, Nd2O3 has wide scale applications in photocatalysis, doping agent in laser devices, magnetic devices, dielectrics [35]. It is known that Nd2O3 exhibits highest basicity among the series of rare earth oxides [36]. Further, base functionalities can be anchored on the surface of GO for obtaining basic properties. For instance, several amines, including ethylene diamine, diethylene triamine and aminosilanes such as 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane, 3-glycidyloxypropyl trimethoxysilane, triethoxysilane etc. have been incorporated which works as base functionalities on surface of GO [37]. Despite GO possessing numerous sites capable of catalyzing several reactions, its application as catalyst for β-nitroamines synthesis via three-constituents nitro-Mannich reaction remains unexplored. Therefore, cost-effective, efficient protocol for the synthesis of β-nitroamines using functionalized GO as heterogeneous catalysts needs a novel approach owing to increasing interest in establishing schemes for organic synthesis. In consistent with our efforts of developing supported heterogeneous catalysts for organic reactions, here, we have synthesized Nd(OH)3 decorated aminopropyl trimethoxy silane (APTMS) functionalized graphene oxide (Nd/APTMS-GO) as multifunctional catalyst. The synthesized catalyst was successfully optimized for production of β-nitroamines via nitro-Mannich reaction using benzaldehyde, aniline and nitromethane as starting substrates without using any solvent which depicts excellent conversion with high selectivity of desired product. Experimental section Synthesis of GO The GO synthesis was conducted by Hummers’ method as described previously [30]. Synthesis of 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane functionalized graphene oxide (APTMS-GO) 1 g of GO was weighed and taken in a glass beaker. 20 ml toluene was poured into it and this suspension was subjected to sonication for 2 h. This suspension was transferred into 3-necked round bottom flask. Into that, 5 ml 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane was added. The system was maintained on constant stirring and allowed to reflux for 15 h at 100 °C. Then, the suspension was centrifuged to separate the precipitates and was given several washings of chloroform till pH becomes neutral. After that, it was dried in hot air oven at 75 °C for couple of days. Synthesis of Nd/APTMS-GO 4 mmol of Nd2O3 was added into a glass beaker containing 0.5 g APTMS-GO. Following that, 20 ml distilled water was poured into it, and the suspension was sonicated for 120 min. This suspension was then transferred to round bottom flask maintained on stirrer at constant stirring and refluxed for 4 h at 90 °C. Then, the suspension was allowed to cool to room temperature and dried in hot air oven for 72 h (Scheme 1 ). Catalytic activity The catalytic efficiency of the synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO was checked by carrying out multicomponent nitro-Mannich reaction. The two-necked round bottom flask (RBF) was filled with 90 mg of Nd-APTMS-f-GO catalyst, 2 mmol of aldehyde, 2 mmol of aniline, and 20 mmol of nitromethane. It was then heated to 90 °C for 6 h while being continuously stirred. Thin layer chromatography was used to track the reaction’s progress. On completion of the reaction, the catalyst was extracted from reaction mixture by centrifugation. This reaction mixture was analyzed using gas chromatography. The recovered catalyst was washed with acetone repeatedly, subsequently air dried in hot air oven at the 80 °C for time period of 2 h before being reused. Results and discussion Fig. 1 illustrates the XRD analysis for the synthesized samples: (a) Nd/APTMS-GO, (b) APTMS-GO (c) GO. The diffraction peaks of pristine GO were observed at 2θ angles of 11.2° and 42°, associated with the (001) and (100) planes, respectively (Fig. 1(c)). Functionalizing GO with 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane results in a new peak at 2θ 26.0°, suggesting that GO has been partially reduced (in-situ reduction) (Fig. 1(b)) [38]. The peak situated at 11.2° persisted but with reduced intensity, signifying partial reduction of graphene oxide. The diffraction peaks of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst are found at 2θ 15.6°, 27.4°, 28.4°, 31.8°, 36.4°, 40.1°, 42.6°, 49.3°, 49.9°, 51.2, 56.5°, 59.4°, 64.8° 66.6°, and 71.4° which are consistent to hexagonal phase for Nd(OH)3 corresponding to JCPDS card no 83–2035 [35]. The peaks observed were well-defined, sharp and narrow confirming that the synthesized catalytic material is crystalline. In addition, the distinct peak of GO can be seen shifted towards lower 2θ angle at 7.74°, denoting intercalation of Nd2O3 between GO layers. The diffraction peak of reduced graphene oxide is not evident in comparison to significant peaks of Nd(OH)3 in synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst, possibly due to crystalline nature of Nd(OH)3. Therefore, XRD evidence shows the effective functionalization of GO with APTMS and Nd(OH)3, and resulting in successful formation of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. The evaluation of functional groups in the synthesized materials i.e., (a) Nd/APTMS-GO, (b) Nd2O3, (c) APTMS-GO, and (d) GO (Fig. 2 ) was performed using Fourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). GO displays stretching vibrations corresponding to different functional groups, with peaks at 3427 and 1720 cm−1 designated for OH and CO functionalities, respectively. The remaining peaks at 1600, 1247, and 1052 cm−1 reflect the presence of CC, COH, and COC (epoxy) groups, respectively (Fig. 2(d)) [22]. On functionalization of GO with APTMS, a broad band corresponding to OH disappears, indicating successful functionalization of OH with amino-silane moieties (Fig. 2(c)). Instead, a small broad band around 3310 cm−1 was observed, suggesting NH stretching of amine. Also, a new peak at 1571 cm−1 was obtained, revealing NH bending of primary amine groups [39]. The bands at 1036, 1123, and 691cm−1 were ascribed to SiO stretching vibrations and SiOC stretching and bending vibrations, respectively; whereas the band at 2884 cm−1 correlated to CH stretching vibrations of aliphatic CH2 groups [40]. Further, it is noteworthy that there has been significant decrease in the intensity of CO peak, indicating partial reduction of GO. Nd2O3 depicts a characteristic broad band at 675 cm−1, which is assigned to the stretching vibration of NdO (Fig. 2(b)). The appearance of sharp peak at 3607 cm−1 is correlated to NdOH bond [35]. The presence of hydroxyl moieties (HOH), i.e., is confirmed by appearance of peak at 3429 (stretching vibrations) and 1640 cm−1 (bending vibrations). The incorporation of Nd2O3 in APTMS-GO to form Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst preserved all the peaks associated to Nd2O3, suggesting successful amalgamation of Nd2O3 with APTMS-GO (Fig. 2(a)). Also, the peaks related to SiO and NH vibrations are retained at 1036 and 1578 cm−1 respectively, indicating successful integration of APTMS-GO. As a result, the FT-IR data shows fruitful functionalization of GO with Nd2O3 and APTMS forming Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. The chemical configuration of the synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst was identified via XPS analysis (Fig. 3 ). The survey spectrum data of Nd/APTMS-GO revealed the presence of Nd, Si, C, N, and O elements (Fig. 3(a)). The distinct characteristic peaks related to Nd 3d, O 1s, N 1s, C 1s, and Si 2p were found at the values of (982.2, 1004.0), 530.4, 398.4, 284.5, and 103.4 eV, respectively. Fig. 3(b) reflects deconvoluted spectrum of the Nd 3d peak, revealing two separate peaks at 1004.0 and 982.2 eV, that corresponded to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 respectively. The satellite peaks were separated from their respective main peaks by approximately 4 eV [41]. This typical spin-orbit splitting indicates existence of Nd3+. The deconvoluted N 1s spectrum of synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst shows two peaks; 398.4 eV for CONH2 and 400.2 eV associated with CH2NH2 respectively (Fig. 3(c)) [31]. Additionally, the deconvoluted O 1s spectra display two peaks at 530.8 and 532.0 eV correspond to surface hydroxyl groups (OH bonds) and/or in the carboxyl groups (CO bonds) and adsorbed oxygen species (Fig. 3(d)) [42,43]. The deconvoluted C 1 s peaks of GO represents four peaks at binding energies of 284.5, 286.0, 287.6, 288.8 and 289.8 eV ascribed to CC, CN, COH, CO, and OCO, respectively (Fig. 3(e)) [44]. Thus, the XPS examination shows that GO has been successfully functionalised with APTMS and Nd2O3. The microstructure, morphology and elemental mapping of synthesized materials i.e. APTMS-GO and Nd/APTMS-GO catalysts, were examined by employing FE-SEM analysis, as presented in Figs. 4 and 5 , respectively, and also examined through HR-TEM, as illustrated in Fig. 6 . The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) investigation was performed for determination of elemental composition of the synthesized nanomaterials (Fig. 4(i,j)). Fig. 4(a–d) depicts flat layered sheet like structure of GO. Also, on closely observing the structure, it can be seen that, a very thin wrinkled layer paper like morphology of partially reduced graphene oxide exists. The EDX analysis of APTMS-GO shows the existence of C, O, Si and N with 47.8, 26.7, 17.6 and 8.0 %, respectively as shown in Fig. 4(i). After decorating APTMS-GO with Nd2O3, the morphology of synthesized material seems to resemble with platelet-like structures agglomerated into small bundles that are scattered on the GO matrix forming close interaction with it, indicating successful functionalization of Nd2O3 and APTMS-GO forming Nd/APTMS-GO [45,46]. Also, the presence of highly thin wavy paper like morphology depicts reduction of some amount of GO to reduced graphene oxide. The EDXanalysis of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst shows presence of C, O, Nd, Si and N with their respective weight percent of 49.0, 26.1, 20.1, 2.5, and 2.3 %, respectively as shown in Fig. 4(j). Fig. 5 shows the elemental mapping of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) analysis was undertaken to acquire micro structural details of the Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst (Fig. 4). Nd(OH)3 nanoparticles are seen to be agglomerated into chunks dispersed irregularly on the surface of GO in the form of small clusters of aggregates (Fig. 6(a–d)) [47]. It possess sponge like morphology with no definite shape (Fig. 6(e–h) whereas GO forms layered sheet like morphology with planar surfaces on which Nd(OH)3 nanoparticles are anchored firmly (Fig. 6 (a-d)) [47,48]. On careful examination, it becomes evident that Nd(OH)3 and GO interact closely, leading to the creation of interfaces between the two materials at several locations (Figure (i)). The size distribution of Nd(OH)3 nanoparticles was examined using ImageJ software, depicting an average size of 46.29 ± 1.38 nm. Furthermore, the lattice spacing was measured to be 0.308 nm, which corresponds to the (200) phase of Nd(OH)3 (Fig. 6(j)). This obtained d-spacing value is equivalent to that observed by XRD examination of hexagonal structure of Nd(OH)3. Further, the diffraction patterns of SAED were found in correlation with the planes obtained in XRD, indicating successful formation of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst. Thermogravimetric analysis was used to evaluate the thermal stability of each manufactured material, as indicated in Fig. 7 . The thermal stability of each synthesized material was examined by plotting their corresponding thermograms. Fig. 7(c) shows thermal stability curve for GO which depicts a total mass loss of around 80 %. The initial loss of 15 % weight is contributed to physically adsorbed water molecules, followed by 13 % weight loss till 300 °C due to oxygen functionalities present on its surface. The remaining carbon component decomposed till 700 °C. Fig. 7(b) depicts the curve for APTMS-GO, where initial weight loss of 5 % till 100 °C is ascribed to physiosorbed molecules of water. The weight loss between 250 and 450 °C is attributed to components of silane condensation reactions on the GO surface. The remaining mass loss from 500 to 700 °C is related to oxidative decomposition of incorporated silanes [37]. It is clearly evident that the thermal stability of APTMS-GO has been improved as compared to GO with overall mass loss of 35 % and 80 %, respectively. Fig. 7(a) depicts the mass loss for synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst, in which initial weight loss of around 3 % is attributed to removal of absorbed water molecules. Subsequently, the weight loss of around 7 to 8 % between 200 and 400 °C is attributed to molar crystalline water as well as oxygen functionalities of GO. The remaining loss between 400 and 800 °C is attributed to loss of hydroxyl moieties, with a total weight loss of only around 15 % [49]. The results indicate that on functionalizing GO with APTMS and Nd(OH)3, the thermal stability is enhanced to much higher extent. Catalytic aptitude The catalytic performance of synthesized the Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst was thoroughly investigated for catalytic CC bond forming condensation reaction using benzaldehyde, aniline and nitromethane as starting substrates resulting into β-nitroamine product (Scheme 2 ). This model reaction was used for optimization of a number of reaction parameters such as solvents, catalyst quantity, temperature and reaction time duration for attaining maximum conversion as well as selectivity and the results are presented in Table 1 . Product analysis was done using gas chromatography. Achieving greater conversion rates requires careful solvent selection because the solvent system is essential to any chemical reaction. The model reaction was explored in several types of solvent systems, which comprises polar and non-polar solvents, namely, toluene, chloroform (CHCl3), acetonitrile (ACN), ethyl acetate (EtOAC), and methanol (MeOH). Preliminary experiments utilizing toluene and chloroform (CHCl3) as solvents yielded conversions of 38.4 %, 32.7 %; with selectivity of 82.3 %, 80.9 %; respectively (Table 1, Entry 1 and 2). Further, employing acetonitrile as a solvent resulted in an increase in conversion to 67.4 %, with the selectivity of 92.4 % (Table 1, Entry 3). The reaction showed significant advancement in polar solvents, i.e., EtOAc (Table 1, Entry 4) and MeOH (Table 1, Entry 5) yielding improved conversion percentages and selectivity. This implies that both catalyst and organic substrates must be dispersed using a solvent with the appropriate polarity [50]. However, the conversion dramatically went up to >99 % with the selectivity of 97.2 % while carrying out the solvent free reaction, i.e., nitromethane itself as a solvent (Table 1, Entry 6). Therefore, the solvent less reaction condition was maintained as more environmentally favourable state. Next, different amounts of catalyst (60, 90, and 120 mg) were examined to find the ideal dose; 90 mg of catalyst produced greatest conversion and selectivity out of all the quantities (Table 1, Entry 7). The selectivity was considerably reduced, despite the fact that the conversion percentage remained unaltered when the dosage was increased to 120 mg (Table 1, Entry 8). This observation reveals that the selectivity of the product may be decreased if the optimal quantity of catalyst is exceeded [26]. As a result, the optimal catalyst dosage was determined to be 90 mg. The influence of temperature was also investigated on a model three-component reaction. The reaction yielded negligible conversions at room temperature (R.T.) (Table 1, entry 9). However, reaction depicted significant conversion at the temperature of 85 °C. On reducing the temperature, lower conversions were observed although selectivity did not alter (Table 1, entry 10). To evaluate the impact of the incorporated functionalities in the synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst, we examined the performance of pristine GO, while keeping every other factor constant. Notably, it exhibits inadequate conversion rates in comparable reaction circumstances (Table 1, entry 11). This highlights the importance of APTMS and Nd2O3 for the advancement of this catalytic process. Additionally, we performed the reaction with pristine Nd2O3 and APTMS which depicted 13 % (Table 1, entry 12) and 8 % (Table 1, entry 13) conversions, respectively which indicates importance of Nd/APTMS-GO. Furthermore, the absence of the catalyst during the reaction resulted in no product formation, emphasising the catalyst's significance in the synthesis process. Thus, these results indicate that functionalized GO serves as a superior catalyst for facilitating this catalytic condensation as compared to pristine GO. Following the optimization of the reaction process, the efficiency of several benzaldehyde derivatives with electron-donating and electron-withdrawing groups was examined. The derivatives exhibited effective synthesis of their corresponding products with high conversions and selectivity (Table 2 ). A proposed catalytic cycle is presented as a tentative mechanism of two steps (Fig. 8 ). The reaction proceeds through two key steps: an initial condensation forming an imine, followed by a nucleophilic addition of a nitroalkane to the in situ generated imine, ultimately yielding the final nitro-Mannich product. In the first step, the Nd(OH)3 likely catalyses the nucleophilic addition of amines to aldehydes, leading to the formation of a hemiaminal intermediate which facilitates removal of water molecule. Deprotonation of the nitroalkane was most likely facilitated by the amine groups present in APTMS, which exhibit greater basicity. The deprotonation of nitroalkane occurs forming a reactive nitronate that attacks the activated imine to yield the nitroamine product, with concurrent regeneration of the catalyst for reuse in the next cycle. The turn over number (TON) and turn over frequency (TOF) values are included in Table 3. Knowing the environmental challenges and economic concern, the potential to be recycled as well as reused is a significant factor for any heterogeneous catalyst. A reusability assessment was conducted by repeating the photocatalytic reaction five times, using the recovered catalyst after each cycle (Fig. 9 ). The Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst was retrieved after every run through centrifugation and subsequently, was given the washings of methanol as well as distilled water. The collected recovered catalyst was dried using hot-air oven prior to its usage in next cycle. After the very first cycle, the catalyst denoted remarkable conversion (98.4 %) and selectivity of 98.5 % for desired nitroamine product. However, after each successive cycle, the catalytic activity decreased progressively and the conversions at the end of each cycle were found to be 91.3, 86.7, 83.8, and 76.2 %. Yet, the selectivity was not did not decrease significantly. The effective reusability of the synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst is reflected in the conversion and selectivity, which remains relatively moderate at the end of 5th cycle, even though there was gradual drop in the conversions. Also, we carried out XRD (Fig. 10 ) and FT-IR (Fig. 11 ) analysis of reused catalyst for confirmation of the structure. The peaks present in XRD as well as in FT-IR match well with those of the fresh catalyst which indicate that the structure of Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst remains intact. ICP-AES analysis of fresh and reused catalyst (after 5th cycle) carried out which depicted 1.73 and 1.28 g/lit, respectively indicating minimal loss of Nd. Conclusion In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst working as multifunctional material by functionalizing GO with APTMS and Nd2O3. This synthesized catalyst was utilized for to facilitate the synthesis of β-nitroamines through nitro-Mannich reaction, which involved the use of three components benzaldehyde, aniline and nitromethane. Exceptional conversion (>99 %) and outstanding selectivity (98.5 %) were achieved for the target product within a duration of 7 h in absence of the solvent system, where nitromethane itself works as solvent. The functionalization of GO with APTMS and Nd2O3 exhibits a significant improvement in the efficiency of catalytic efficiency relative to pristine GO. Furthermore, the Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst revealed demonstrated significant recyclability for five cycles, exhibiting a slight decline in the conversion with moderate drop in conversion of the desired product. This study highlights the importance of functionalized GO in the advancement of cost-effective, sustainable, and eco-friendly catalytic processes. coredata.dc:description: This study reveals fabrication of multifunctional catalytic system by integrating graphene oxide, neodymium trioxide (Nd2O3), and 3-aminopropyl trimethoxy silane (APTMS) leading to the formation of Nd/APTMS-GO. The synthesized Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst was characterized through several methods and was successfully employed as a catalyst for β-nitroamines synthesis via nitro-Mannich, i.e., aza-Henry reaction using benzaldehyde, aniline and nitromethane. This reaction was carried out without using any solvent. The reaction achieved an excellent conversion rate of 92.18 % and a high selectivity of 98.5 % towards the desired product, β-nitroamines, within time span of 8 h. Moreover, Nd/APTMS-GO catalyst revealed notable recyclability for over five cycles with moderate drop in conversion of the desired product.

coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of β-nitroamines via nitro-Mannich reaction using Nd/APTMS decorated graphene oxide
